Award.AbstractNarration:
Advanced Grid-Enabled Algorithms to Discover Conformations of Proteins
Proteins are molecular machines that need to move in order to function. Computationally one can model their motion according to physical equations of motion that are weighted according to an energy function. Discovery of the shapes or conformations of proteins is a sampling problem in a very high dimensional space, and thus difficult. Solving this problem can assist in the discovery of biologically relevant intermediates of reactions, design of new medicinal drugs, and better characterization of their biological function.
This proposal will develop new algorithms and software to discover the conformations of proteins. We exploit distributed or grid computing to pursue exploration of the conformational space. We use a dimensionality reduction approach where the search is confined to the slowest and most collective motions of the protein. This greatly accelerates sampling and is scalable to large proteins. We will apply our technique in two algorithms, replica exchange and the on-the-fly string method. Replica exchange uses multiple simulations at different temperatures and performs periodic exchanges among them to achieve annealing. The string method finds a minimum free energy path that connects two known conformations of a protein: for instance, inactive to active enzyme. Our technique automatically finds ?slow? and collective variables along which to search conformations.
Intellectual merit: Our methods hold promise to accelerate the search by 3 or more orders of magnitude, opening entirely new avenues of research related to large conformational changes that happen over long timescales for larger proteins.
Broader impacts: These algorithms will be released as open source software with a Python interface and GPU-accelerated implementations, and will be able to use large distributed systems. Validation will be done on a specific protein system for which experimental data is available.
In collaboration with the Shodor Foundation, we will involve high school students and teachers in developing web content in support of the work on this proposal. We will explore whether including these materials in courses raises interest in computational biology or biology or computation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding how proteins fold in order to maintain a healthy cell is one of the central problems of molecular cell biology. Computer simulations can yield atomic level details that complement experiments in order to yield insights that can help us understand how failure in homeostasis of protein folding results in diseases such as Type-I diabetes and Alzheimer's. 

 

However, there are great challenges in being able to carry out these simulations at the scale needed to gain statistically significant insight. This grant produced several technologies that accelerate by several orders of magnitude the ability of simulations of protein folding to produce insight. This include methods developed for graphics cards (GPUs) and for thousands of computing resources distributed in the cloud.

 

The published research findings and software tools are a step forward in the state-of-the-art for these simulations techniques. It is the hope of the PI and his collaborators that at the same time this is a stepping stone for even broader impacts of this work, by applying it to many other biological molecules, removing remaining roadblocks to its highest performance, and by extending it to other exciting new fields. 

 

Breaking the time scale barrier is an important contribution that may vastly improve our understanding of protein folding and misfolding, protein-protein interactions, design of small molecules that bind to promising but challenging protein targets, and design of new materials.
